natural problem: Let $f(x) = 12x+7$ and $g(x) = 5x+2$ whenever $x$ is a positive integer. Define $h(x)$ to be the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$. What is the sum of all possible values of $h(x)$?
natural solution: Use the Euclidean algorithm on $f(x)$ and $g(x)$. \begin{align} h(x) &= \gcd(f(x), g(x)) \\ &= \gcd(12x+7, 5x+2) \\ &= \gcd(5x+2, (12x+7)-2(5x+2)) \\ &= \gcd(5x+2, 2x + 3) \\ &= \gcd(2x+3, (5x+2)-2(2x+3)) \\

&= \gcd(2x+3, x - 4) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, (2x+3)-2(x-4)) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, 11) \end{align}From applying the Euclidean algorithm, we have that the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is 11 if and only if $x-4$ is a multiple of 11.

For example, note that $f(4) = 55$ and $g(4) = 22$, and the greatest common divisor of 55 and 22 turns out to be 11. If $x-4$ is not a multiple of 11, then the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ must be one, since 11 is prime and therefore has no other factors.
It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: nat and f g h :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 12 * x + 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 5 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. h x = gcd (f x) (g x)"
shows  "sum h {n. n \<in> UNIV} = 12"

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof
 Use the Euclidean algorithm on $f(x)$ and $g(x)$. \begin{align} h(x) &= \gcd(f(x), g(x)) \\ &= \gcd(12x+7, 5x+2) \\ &= \gcd(5x+2, (12x+7)-2(5x+2)) \\ &= \gcd(5x+2, 2x + 3) \\ &= \gcd(2x+3, (5x+2)-2(2x+3)) \\
 &= \gcd(2x+3, x - 4) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, (2x+3)-2(x-4)) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, 11) \end{align}From applying the Euclidean algorithm, we have that the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is 11 if and only if $x-4$ is a multiple of 11.
 For example, note that $f(4) = 55$ and $g(4) = 22$, and the greatest common divisor of 55 and 22 turns out to be 11. If $x-4$ is not a multiple of 11, then the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ must be one, since 11 is prime and therefore has no other factors.
 It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.

theorem
fixes x :: nat and f g h :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 12 * x + 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 5 * x + 2"

theorem
fixes f g h :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"

and h1 : "\<forall>x. g x = 5 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. h x = gcd (f x) (g x)"
shows  "(\<Sum>x. h x) = 12"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 &= \gcd(2x+3, x - 4) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, (2x+3)-2(x-4)) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, 11) \end{align}From applying the Euclidean algorithm, we have that the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is 11 if and only if $x-4$ is a multiple of 11.
 For example, note that $f(4) = 55$ and $g(4) = 22$, and the greatest common divisor of 55 and 22 turns out to be 11. If $x-4$ is not a multiple of 11, then the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ must be one, since 11 is prime and therefore has no other factors.
 It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.
 *)

and h2 : "\<forall> x. h x = gcd (f x) (g x)"
shows  "sum h {x. x \<in> UNIV} = 12"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.
 *)

shows  "sum h {x. x \<in> {1..}} = 12"

(* ### Problem

 &= \gcd(2x+3, x - 4) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, (2x+3)-2(x-4)) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, 11) \end{align}From applying the Euclidean algorithm, we have that the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is 11 if and only if $x-4$ is a multiple of 11.
 For example, note that $f(4) = 55$ and $g(4) = 22$, and the greatest common divisor of 55 and 22 turns out to be 11. If $x-4$ is not a multiple of 11, then the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ must be one, since 11 is prime and therefore has no other factors.
 It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.
 *)

theorem

assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> f x = 12 * x + 7"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> g x = 5 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> h x = gcd (f x) (g x)"
shows  "sum h {x. x > 0} = 12"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 &= \gcd(2x+3, x - 4) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, (2x+3)-2(x-4)) \\ &= \gcd(x-4, 11) \end{align}From applying the Euclidean algorithm, we have that the greatest common divisor of $f(x)$ and $g(x)$ is 11 if and only if $x-4$ is a multiple of 11.

 It follows that $h(x)$ can take on two distinct values; 1 and 11. The sum of all possible values of $h(x)$ is therefore $1 + 11 = \boxed{12}$.
 *)

 *)

theorem
fixes f g h :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> f x = 12 * x + 7"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> g x = 5 * x + 2"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. x > 0 \<longrightarrow> h x = gcd (f x) (g x)"
shows  "sum h {x. x > 0} = 12"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Given the functions $f(x)=12x+7$, $g(x)=5x+2$, and $h(x)=\gcd(f(x),g(x))$ for all positive integers $x$, find the sum of $h(x)$ over all positive integers. The final answer is 12.
